interest) would continue at its present level. One hundred
fifty three educational radio stations now receive a minimum
of five hours of taped programming per week.
Phase II (January 1, 1970 to December 31, 1970)
The program duplication activity would be augmented by a
Radio Public Affairs Bureau. This unit will produce, record
and duplicate additional taped broadcasts at a minimum level
of two hours per week. The Public Affairs Bureau will provide
a daily audio news service via telephone tape to educational
radio stations.
Phase III (January 1, 1971 to December 31, 1971)
Continue and expand the activities initiated in Phase I and
II. Expand facilities, equipment, space and staff to provide
for an independent production center for programs to be
distributed via a National Public Radio System. It is en¬
visioned that such a system will be developed (see Implemen¬
tation Section) by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.
